categories.DESCRIPTION: Explores how sound travels, what causes sounds, and how we hear them. Helps children understand that sound is a physical phenomenon they can observe and experiment with in their environment.
categories.EXAMPLE_ACTIVITIES: Creating simple musical instruments from household items to explore pitch and volume; Using tuning forks in water to see sound waves; Feeling throat vibrations while humming different notes

categories.DESCRIPTION: Introduces basic mechanical devices that make work easier through hands-on exploration. Builds understanding of how everyday tools work and how forces can be redirected or amplified.
categories.EXAMPLE_ACTIVITIES: Building and testing ramps at different angles; Using pulleys to lift lightweight objects; Creating a lever system with a ruler and fulcrum

categories.DESCRIPTION: Investigates how light travels, interacts with objects, and creates shadows. Connects to daily observations of natural and artificial light while introducing basic concepts of reflection and opacity.
categories.EXAMPLE_ACTIVITIES: Shadow puppet theater with different light sources; Making rainbows with prisms; Testing which materials block or allow light to pass through

categories.DESCRIPTION: Explores magnetic forces and their effects on various materials. Introduces the concept of invisible forces while allowing for safe and engaging hands-on discovery.
categories.EXAMPLE_ACTIVITIES: Testing which household items are magnetic; Creating magnetic art with iron filings; Making a floating magnetic sculpture

categories.DESCRIPTION: Focuses specifically on how materials can change from one state to another through heating and cooling. Builds on children's experiences with everyday substances like water, chocolate, and butter.
categories.EXAMPLE_ACTIVITIES: Making popsicles and observing melting; Watching steam condense on a cool surface; Creating and melting crayon art

categories.DESCRIPTION: Investigates center of gravity, weight distribution, and what makes things stay upright or fall over. Connects to children's natural curiosity about building and stacking while introducing fundamental physics concepts.
categories.EXAMPLE_ACTIVITIES: Building and testing block towers of different shapes; Creating mobiles that balance; Exploring how to make spinning tops stay upright

skills.DESCRIPTION: Identify and differentiate between various environmental sounds (loud/soft, near/far, natural/artificial)
skills.CONNECTIONS: Language Arts (descriptive vocabulary), Social Studies (environmental awareness)

skills.DESCRIPTION: Recognize that sounds are created by vibrations through simple demonstrations (rubber bands, drums, voice box)
Demonstrate understanding that sound travels through different materials (air, water, solids) through experiments
Create and control sounds of different volumes and understand the concept of amplitude
Create and repeat simple sound patterns using classroom instruments or body percussion
Draw or chart different sounds heard in various locations and categorize them
Explore and understand how sounds can bounce back (basic echo concept) through experimentation
Create simple musical instruments using household materials to demonstrate sound production
skills.PREREQUISITES: Vibration Basics, Sound Travel, Volume Exploration

skills.DESCRIPTION: Recognize and name the six basic simple machines (lever, wheel and axle, pulley, inclined plane, wedge, and screw) in everyday objects
Demonstrate understanding that simple machines help us push and pull things more easily through hands-on experimentation
Identify and explain how simple machines are used in playground equipment (slides as inclined planes, seesaws as levers)
skills.PREREQUISITES: Machine Identification, Push and Pull Forces
skills.CONNECTIONS: Physical Education, Social Skills, Safety Awareness

skills.DESCRIPTION: Sort common tools and objects by the type of simple machine they represent (hammer as lever, screwdriver as wheel and axle)
Experiment with different inclined plane angles to observe how they affect the speed and effort needed to move objects
Create and test simple vehicles using wheels and axles to understand how they make movement easier
skills.PREREQUISITES: Machine Identification, Push and Pull Forces

skills.DESCRIPTION: Use simple levers to solve basic weight-lifting challenges, understanding the concept of effort and load
skills.PREREQUISITES: Push and Pull Forces, Playground Physics

skills.DESCRIPTION: Identify and explain how multiple simple machines work together in common objects (scissors use both levers and wedges)
Create basic drawings or models of new tools using simple machines to solve a given problem
skills.PREREQUISITES: Machine Identification, Tool Classification, Push and Pull Forces

skills.DESCRIPTION: Identify and name different sources of light (sun, lamps, flashlights, etc.) and distinguish between natural and artificial light sources
Demonstrate understanding that shadows form when light is blocked by an object
skills.CONNECTIONS: Cause and Effect Reasoning, Spatial Awareness

skills.DESCRIPTION: Match objects to their shadows and predict shadow shapes based on object profiles
Explore how shadow size changes based on object distance from light source
Experiment with how changing light direction affects shadow position and orientation
Sort materials based on whether light passes through them (transparent) or creates shadows (opaque)
Create and manipulate simple shadow puppets to tell stories
skills.PREREQUISITES: Shadow Formation Basics, Shadow Shape Matching
skills.CONNECTIONS: Creative Arts, Storytelling, Fine Motor Skills

skills.DESCRIPTION: Observe and record how outdoor shadows change throughout the day due to sun position
skills.PREREQUISITES: Shadow Formation Basics, Light Direction Testing
skills.CONNECTIONS: Earth Science, Time Concepts, Data Recording

skills.DESCRIPTION: Identify and demonstrate that magnets can attract certain objects from a distance without touching them
skills.CONNECTIONS: Motor skills, Observation, Scientific method basics

skills.DESCRIPTION: Sort and classify objects into groups based on whether they are attracted to magnets or not
Compare the strength of different magnets by measuring how many paper clips each can hold in a chain
Explore and demonstrate how magnetic poles attract and repel each other
Use iron filings to observe and describe the invisible magnetic field around magnets
Investigate how magnetic forces work through different materials and thicknesses
Design and build simple games using magnets (e.g., magnetic fishing, maze navigation)
Identify and explain how magnets are used in everyday objects (refrigerator, toys, cabinet latches)
skills.CONNECTIONS: Technology awareness, Environmental observation, Communication skills

skills.DESCRIPTION: Identify and describe basic properties of solids and liquids using simple terms (hard, soft, flows, holds shape)
skills.CONNECTIONS: Language Arts (descriptive vocabulary), Daily Life (identifying common materials)

skills.DESCRIPTION: Observe and predict how temperature changes affect common materials (melting ice, freezing water)
Recognize and describe how water can change between solid, liquid, and gas forms
skills.CONNECTIONS: Weather (rain, snow, clouds), Kitchen Science (cooking, freezing)

skills.DESCRIPTION: Identify signs that matter has changed state (melting, freezing, evaporation) through observation
Demonstrate understanding that some changes in matter can be reversed (ice to water and back)
Group materials based on their ability to change states under normal conditions
Make simple predictions about how materials will change under different conditions
Document observations of matter changes through drawings and simple words
Design and conduct simple experiments to test how materials change states
Identify and mark the center point of various simple objects like blocks, rulers, and paper shapes
Build stable towers using 3-5 blocks by aligning their centers and understanding basic vertical balance
Explore and predict outcomes on a simple balance beam using equal weights on both sides
Compare and sort objects by weight using hands and simple balance scales
Practice personal balance through simple physical activities like standing on one foot and walking on lines
Identify and describe why certain structures are stable or unstable using basic engineering vocabulary
Discover which 3D shapes are more stable for building and why (pyramids vs. cubes vs. cylinders)
Create and maintain balance in asymmetrical arrangements using different sized objects and weights
Investigate how different types and numbers of support points affect stability in structures

subskills.ACTIVITY: Play "Sound Detective" where students close their eyes and raise one finger for soft sounds (whisper) and two fingers for loud sounds (clapping)
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student correctly identifies 8/10 sounds as either loud or soft in a listening exercise

subskills.SUBSKILL: Identify the direction a sound is coming from
subskills.ACTIVITY: "Marco Polo" style game where students point to where they hear a bell ringing while blindfolded
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student accurately points to sound source in 4/5 attempts

subskills.SUBSKILL: Match common environmental sounds to pictures
subskills.ACTIVITY: Sound matching game with cards showing pictures (dog, car, bird) paired with recorded sounds
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student matches 6/8 sound-picture pairs correctly

subskills.SUBSKILL: Distinguish between natural and human-made sounds
subskills.ACTIVITY: Sort picture cards into two groups (natural/human-made) while listening to corresponding sounds
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student correctly categorizes 7/10 sounds as natural or human-made

subskills.ACTIVITY: Listen to recorded sounds and place markers on a simple distance map (close, medium, far)
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student correctly places 5/6 sound markers on distance map

subskills.SUBSKILL: Create and describe different sound patterns
subskills.ACTIVITY: Use simple instruments to create patterns (loud-soft-loud, soft-soft-loud)
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student creates and accurately describes 3 different sound patterns

subskills.SUBSKILL: Compare and contrast two different sounds
subskills.ACTIVITY: Listen to paired sounds and use picture cards to identify similarities and differences
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student identifies at least one similarity and one difference for 4/5 sound pairs

subskills.ACTIVITY: Students gently place fingers on their throat while humming different notes, identifying the buzzing sensation
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can accurately describe the feeling and point to where they feel vibrations

subskills.ACTIVITY: Students tap drums with water drops on top, observing water movement when drum is struck
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can explain what happens to water drops when drum is hit and why

subskills.ACTIVITY: Students stretch rubber bands across empty boxes, plucking to make different sounds
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can demonstrate how to make both high and low sounds using rubber bands

subskills.ACTIVITY: Students experiment with hitting drums softly vs. strongly, observing differences in sound and feeling
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can explain that stronger hits make louder sounds and bigger vibrations

subskills.ACTIVITY: Students explore classroom items (bell, triangle, tuning fork) to find which ones vibrate when making sound
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can sort 6 items into "vibrates to make sound" and "doesn't vibrate to make sound" categories

subskills.ACTIVITY: Students experiment with dampening vibrations (touching a ringing bell, placing hand on drum) to stop sound
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can demonstrate and explain how to stop a sound by stopping vibrations

subskills.ACTIVITY: Students use simple instruments to create repeating patterns of loud/soft vibrations
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can create and repeat a simple pattern of three different sounds using vibrating objects

subskills.SUBSKILL: Identify that sounds create vibrations you can feel
subskills.ACTIVITY: Place fingers gently on throat while humming different notes; feel rice grains on a drum surface while striking it
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can accurately describe and point to where they feel vibrations when making sounds

subskills.SUBSKILL: Recognize that sound travels through air
subskills.ACTIVITY: Play "telephone" game with paper cup phones connected by string; observe sound getting softer with distance
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can explain that sound travels from one cup to another and gets quieter farther away

subskills.ACTIVITY: Tap underwater objects in a water bin while partially submerging ears (with adult supervision)
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can describe hearing sounds underwater and compare to above-water sounds

subskills.SUBSKILL: Explore sound travel through solid objects
subskills.ACTIVITY: Press ear against table while partner gently taps on different spots; use spoons on string as wind chimes
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can successfully detect and locate sounds traveling through solid materials

subskills.SUBSKILL: Compare sound travel speed in different materials
subskills.ACTIVITY: Strike tuning fork against different materials (wood, metal, plastic) and observe differences
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can order materials from fastest to slowest sound travel based on observations

subskills.ACTIVITY: Test different materials (cotton, foam, cardboard) to muffle sounds from a small music player
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can predict and test which materials will block sound better

subskills.ACTIVITY: Create megaphones from paper cones; experiment with different sizes and materials
subskills.ASSESSMENT: Student can demonstrate how their device makes sounds louder and explain basic reasoning
